candidates.title: Combine protobuf_build crate into tari_common
candidates.body: In support of #1211

candidates.title: Remove empty folder and unused code for testnet
candidates.body:
Delete old, obsolete and unused code ahead of testnet launch.
We don't want to confuse folks with code that won't run or have
unnecessary folders with nothing in them.

Code can be recovered from the git history if any of these projects need
to be resurrected. For rference, the following folders were deleted:

* grpc_wallet
* console_text_messenger
* cli_wallet
* tari_miner
* tari_pool_miner
* base_layer/mining
* digital_assets_layer
* doc (about as outdated as anything in here :/)

And some bash scripts were updated to reflect this.

candidates.title: Use external pubsub and broadcast_channel repos
candidates.body:
The pubsub and broadcast channel crates have been moved to their own
repos at github.com/tari-project.

This PR removes the source code from this repo and updates `Cargo.toml`
files to use the new crates.

candidates.title: Integrate the Comms Event Bus feedback into the Wallet Send Transaction
candidates.body:
## Description
The Comms stack now has an event bus that informs you when a message has been successfully sent where before you only knew it had been queued for sending after a discovery process has been successful.

This PR updates the Transaction Service to start monitoring the Messaging Events to wait for the confirmation that the message has sent or failed to send. If the message failed to send the client application will be informed via a Callback that the transaction Failed to send.

## Motivation and Context
Closes https://github.com/tari-project/tari/issues/1260

## How Has This Been Tested?
Tests updated and provided

## Types of changes

* [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

candidates.title: Added onion v3 address support + Detach mode
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
- `/onion3/` support added (for multiaddr and socks5 client)
- Comms will create a onion v3 hidden service when running in tor mode
- Support detach mode when adding an onion address so that it can stay active
  after comms has shut down, possibly reducing the time to first byte
  on startup.
- Changed wallet ffi to (de)serialize tor identity instead of just the
  private key.
- Changed `tor_private_key_file` to `tor_identity_file` in base node
  config


## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1338 #1352 

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
New test for multiline responses in tor control client. Working tor example and running base node over onionv3.

candidates.title: Removed tower_filter crate
candidates.body:
tower_filter crate was preventing us from publishing comms/dht. It is
still not published in 0.3.1 so I added it as a module in dht.

candidates.title: Allow transports to be configured for base node
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->

The following keys now work in base_node.mainnet and base_node.testnet config sections:
```toml
// Select one transport
// TCP
transport = "tcp"
tcp_listener_address = "/ip4/0.0.0.0/tcp/18189"

// TOR
transport = "tor"
tor_control_address = "/ip4/127.0.0.1/tcp/9051"
tor_control_auth = "none" # or "password=xxxxxx"
tor_onion_port = 18141
tor_forward_address = "/ip4/127.0.0.1/tcp/18141"

// SOCKS
transport = "socks5"
socks5_proxy_address = "/ip4/127.0.0.1/tcp/9050"
socks5_listener_address = "/ip4/127.0.0.1/tcp/18189"
socks5_auth = "none" # or "username_password=username:xxxxxxx"

tor_private_key_file = "~/.tari/mainnet/tor.key"
```

## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1362 

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
Ran a base node over tor

candidates.title: Make cursive an optional dependency
candidates.body:
`ncurses` is just used for the pingpong example, however it is not available on windows and
so prevents windows users from compiling the tari source.

This PR makes the `cursive` library optional under the `pingpong-example` feature flag

candidates.title: Migrated codebase over to new comms
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
- Removed deprecated modules from comms.
- Changes to comms builder to allow for DHT pipelines to work
- Improvements to reliability of messaging protocol handler
- Perf improvement by removing per message peer query
- New sinumtaneous test
- Connection manager will give clients some advanced notification before
  shutting down a connection in a tie-break situation
- CommsNode::shutdown returns a future which resolves once some comms
  services have shut down, allowing for a cleaner shutdown and for the
  last internal events/messages to be processed before closing the
  process/test
- TransportType enum for convinient configuration
- Changed LivenessService default to not send auto joins and SAF (in tests, this is unnecessary overhead. Better to explicitly enable them)
- Updated base node and wallet code where applicable

## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1326 

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
Extensive unit tests. TODO: extensive integration tests.

candidates.title: Convert node id to 104 bits
candidates.body: A 104-bit node id is compliant with RFC-152/EmojiIds

candidates.title: Use the tari_crypto crate
candidates.body:
Migrate to using the tari_crypto crate rather than the local
source copy.

This required changing all the Cargo.toml files;
and enabled us to remove the dependency on `tari_utilities`
in most cases.

The one-line macro for including protobuf files was removed to
further reduce the need for using tari_utilities in several
places.

ref #1211

candidates.title: Tor hidden service builder + more logs + tor example
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
- Added HiddenServiceBuilder to setup a new or existing Tor Hidden Service
- Allow comms to configure itself (specifically, configure itself to use
      the SOCKS5 proxy) to use a given Hidden Service.
- The private key for the hidden service could be persisted and re-used
      later. The implementation for that is left to client code.
- Added `GETINFO` support to tor control port client
- Added a tor ping pong example.
- Had to change `Transport` trait and `TcpTransport` to get around Rust ICE 

```rust
    let tor_hidden_service = tor::HiddenServiceBuilder::new()
        .with_port_mapping(port_mapping)
        .with_control_server_address(control_port_addr)
        .finish()
        .await?;

let private_key = tor_hidden_service.private_key();
// Securely persist the private key which can be used to restore the onion address later.

    let comms_node =  CommsBuilder::new()
        .configure_from_hidden_service(&tor_hidden_service)
        // (...)
      .spawn()
      .await?;

```

## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1100. Create a seamless tor integration for tari_comms.

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
Tested using the tor example - more fine grained tests are TODO, although the control port client library is extensively tested.

To run the example - start the tor proxy (ensuring that the `ControlPort 9051` setting is set in `torrc`) and run
`cargo run --example tor --features next -- /ip4/127.0.0.1/tcp/9051`

candidates.title: Added Tor control port client module
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
The tor control port allows an authenticated client to issue commands to
the tor proxy daemon using an SMTP-like protocol.

[Tor control port spec](https://gitweb.torproject.org/torspec.git/tree/control-spec.txt)

This PR adds a client library with support for three commands, namely `ADD_ONION`,
`DEL_ONION` and `GET_CONF`. Further commands can be added as/when they
are needed.

## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1100 - This will allow zero-config tor hidden services for wallets and nodes.

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
Unit tests for each command using a mock server which serves canned responses. These canned responses were copied from a running tor proxy.

## Types of changes
<!--- What types of changes does your code introduce? Put an `x` in all the boxes that apply: -->
* [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
* [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
* [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to change)

candidates.title: Add testnet faucet generator
candidates.body:
To help wallet users get some testnet Tari to play with, we're
adding some utxos to the genesis block that they can claim
from their mobile wallet apps.

This PR add a small application that generates the faucet UTXOs
and private keys.

The UTXOs will be added to the alpha-net genesis block.

The `create_utxo` helper function was extended to accept `OutputFeatures`

candidates.title: Comms builder for fully-async comms node
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
Comms builder is the public interface for building a comms node. This PR
is an iteration on the previous builder which brings together all the new
async services.

It now handles hooking up the inbound and outbound "pipelines"
to the /tari/messaging protocol. (This used to be an external
responsibility). This interface is fully compatible with the existing pipeline (dht, tari_p2p etc)

It also allows custom protocols to be added.

An example initialization:

```rust
  let comms_node = CommsBuilder::new()
        .with_listener_address("/ip4/0.0.0.0/tcp/0".parse().unwrap())
        .with_transport(TcpTransport::default())
        .with_peer_storage(HashmapDatabase::new())
        .with_messaging_pipeline(
            pipeline::Builder::new()
                // Outbound messages will be forwarded "as is" to outbound messaging
                .with_outbound_pipeline(outbound_rx, std::convert::identity)
               // Up to 10 inbound messages concurrently processed by the given pipeline 
                .max_concurrent_inbound_tasks(10)
                // Inbound messages will be forwarded "as is" to inbound_tx
                .with_inbound_pipeline(SinkService::new(inbound_tx))
                .finish(),
        )
        .with_node_identity(node_identity)
        .with_protocols(
           Protocols::new()
             // Add protocol ids and notifiers (mpsc::Sender). Notifications are sent when a peer wants to speak a particular protocol
               .add(&[MY_CUSTOM_PROTOCOL_v1, MY_CUSTOM_PROTOCOL_v2], my_custom_notif)
               .add(&[DHT_PROTOCOL], dht_notif)
               .add(&[MEMPOOL_PROTOCOL], mempool_notif)
        )
        .spawn()
        .await
        .unwrap();
```


## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1235 

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
New tests testing the custom protocol and messaging protocol setup with the new comms builder.

## Types of changes
<!--- What types of changes does your code introduce? Put an `x` in all the boxes that apply: -->
* [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
* [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
* [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to change)
* [x] Feature refactor (No new feature or functional changes, but performance or technical debt improvements)
* [x] New Tests

candidates.title: Bump tari_utilities minor version
candidates.body:
Bumping tari_utilities to v0.1.0

"External" crates, inc tari_crypto depend on tari_utilies.
Therefore it should keep to semver conventions.
To keep with semver conventions, breaking changes must
increase the minor version.

Since moving to rand v0.7 introduced breaking changes, we bump the minor
version.

candidates.title: Implement wallet base node monitoring for broadcast transactions
candidates.body:
## Description

This PR implements base node monitoring for the Wallet to periodically ask a base_node if a pending CompletedTransaction has been mined yet.

When a Completed transaction is detected as broadcast to the mempool the Wallet will start querying the base_node for the outputs that have been mined.

When the wallet starts up it will go through stored completed transactions and check which have the broadcast state and start monitoring them for being mined

## Motivation and Context
Closes https://github.com/tari-project/tari/issues/640
Closes https://github.com/tari-project/tari/issues/888
Closes https://github.com/tari-project/tari/issues/887

## How Has This Been Tested?
Tests provided

candidates.title: Inbound and outbound messaging handlers for /tari/messaging
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
InboundMessaging component decodes, verifies and transforms incoming
messaging bytes into an InboundMessage containing the Envelope

OutboundMessaging component is lazily spawned when sending a message to a peer,
once per peer messaging 'session'. It ensures that a peer connection
exists (dialing the peer if required), as well as a substream.

Both of these components will replace the IMS and OMS respectively.

EXTRA: 

- Breaking changes in unbounded channels which were breaking reply_chanel tests - fixed. 
- Use `Bytes` for `InboundMessage` an `OutboundMessage` (zero copy!) 

## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1276 

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
Message protocol smoke tests sending and receiving messages

candidates.title: Removes tari_comms_middleware crate

candidates.title: Added fire-and-forget Messaging protocol handler
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
- Added protocol `/tari/messaging/0.1.0`
- This protocol handler handles inbound and outbound messaging.
- The node must already be connected to the peer before sending/receiving messages.
- Peers sending `/tari/messaging/0.1.0` messages between each other open
  two substreams (lazily, as needed), one for inbound and one for
  outbound.
- Outbound messages are sent as a request to MessagingProtocol. If a
  substream is not open for this peer, one is opened and 'cached' for
  future message sends.
- This protocol handler will be hooked up to the existing OMS and IMS.
  Essentially it is the glue between the existing fire-and-forget functionality
  and the async multiplexed connections.


## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1202

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
New mocks for connection manager and peer connection. Wrote outbound, inbound and error case tests.

candidates.title: Miner wallet integration
candidates.body:
## Description
Miner wallet integration.
Cleanup the miner code and moved mining to a blocking thread.

## Motivation and Context
The miner needs to be able to submit a utxo to the wallet. The miner cannot contain a wallet as this will cause a cycle dependancy. The base node will act as a mediator between the two. The miner gives a channel out to the base node which will sit and listen for an unblindedUTXO which it will give to wallet

The miner code has also been moved to a blocking thread as spawning a task is not the most efficient use of blocking task. The mining task will wait for the blocking thread to return and does not use a thread anymore with channels to communicate internally. 

## Types of changes
* [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
* [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
* [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to change)
* [x] Feature refactor (No new feature or functional changes, but performance or technical debt improvements)
* [ ] New Tests
* [ ] Documentation

candidates.title: Simultaneous connection tie breaking
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
If peers dial each other at the same time there must be a way for both
peers to deterministically choose which connection to keep and which to
disconnect.

This PR adds code to handle this situation by using the NodeID and
ConnectionDirection to enable both sides to agree on a connection to
close.

Extra: Since async tests are moving towards to running in an async context (through `#[tokio_macros::test]` - tests should probably change to use this) it no longer makes sense to use `tari_test_utils::runtime` and `Runtime::block_on` everywhere.  I changed `tari_test_utils::collect_stream!` to rather work in an async context. 

## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1153 

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
Tested by having two connection managers simultaneously dial each other and checking the events produced. Since the tie breaking is transparent to the outside api, it is not tested directly. More work needs to happen to make this easier to unit test.

## Types of changes
<!--- What types of changes does your code introduce? Put an `x` in all the boxes that apply: -->
* [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
* [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

candidates.title: Added bounded executor
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
Spawning an unbounded number of tasks in response to e.g. a network message
is dangerous because an attacker could exploit this to cause a node to become
unresponsive/use excessive system resources.

This PR adds a `BoundedExecutor` which wraps the tokio executor and a
semaphore to asynchronously block calls to spawn should all the semaphore
permits be used. This should cause backpressure on the requesting peer.
For e.g. new requests won't be handled until a permit has been
released.

BONUS: removed some unused dependencies

## Types of changes
<!--- What types of changes does your code introduce? Put an `x` in all the boxes that apply: -->
* [ ] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
* [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
* [ ] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to change)
* [ ] Feature refactor (No new feature or functional changes, but performance or technical debt improvements)

candidates.title: Added and integrated identity protocol into connection manager
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
- When peers connect their identity is exchanged. This includes
  node id, addresses and peer features.
- This protocol is run on inbound and outbound connections
- The identity is used to add a peer to the peer manager as part of
  establishing a connection.
- If this protocol fails, the connection will be dropped/rejected.
- Yamux wrapper now drives the incoming stream in a background task as part of 
   the upgrade process. Meaning it JustWorks(tm).

## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1152 

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
Unit test for protocol. Updated smoke test for dialer/listener components

candidates.title: Origin in DHT message is now optional, hash of message for dedup
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
- Origin data (public key and signature) are optional to preserve
  privacy for appropriate messages (e.g. transactions, blocks)
- If the origin is omitted, the message is from the peer
  sending the message over a secure channel
- The deduping of messages uses a hash of the message contents, not the
   origin signature. This is to prevent a duplicate message signed by a
   different party from being let through.
- SAF storage keeps a copy of cleartext messages that have an origin
  specified
- Shared SAF storage access uses the blocking threadpool


## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1241 

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
Unit tests for new SAF behaviour.

## Types of changes
<!--- What types of changes does your code introduce? Put an `x` in all the boxes that apply: -->
* [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
* [ ] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)
* [x] Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to change)
* [x] Feature refactor (No new feature or functional changes, but performance or technical debt improvements)

chosen_pr.title: Remove empty folder and unused code for testnet
chosen_pr.body:
Delete old, obsolete and unused code ahead of testnet launch.
We don't want to confuse folks with code that won't run or have
unnecessary folders with nothing in them.

Code can be recovered from the git history if any of these projects need
to be resurrected. For rference, the following folders were deleted:

* grpc_wallet
* console_text_messenger
* cli_wallet
* tari_miner
* tari_pool_miner
* base_layer/mining
* digital_assets_layer
* doc (about as outdated as anything in here :/)

And some bash scripts were updated to reflect this.
